instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.AP_PWR_EN: What is AP_PWR_EN? AP_PWR_EN is a signal that enables power for the wifi circuit and wifi card. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no wifi, Io0r error
threads.message:
working on this liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, after u.c. the board powered on but had no wifi, and left shift key not working, also io0r sensor reading above hight point.

i got the shift key issue taken care of by replacing the keyboard connector. 

Io0R current sensor is reading 10.999 a -I did check the <CHIP>U5410</CHIP> area all looks good
pin3 3.31v
pin4 12.55v
pin5 12.48v
pin6 3.31v

not sure if this would be a smc issue or something else.

Then no wifi has me mixed up also
After changing wifi card and cable, checking for crap inside the connector i noticed i wasn't getting voltage out of <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> so i changed it after checking the resistors and caps, but still no voltage out and no short to ground. not sure if the Io0R problem is causing the no wifi issue. would it be possible to run 3.3v from one side of <TRANSISTOR>Q3550</TRANSISTOR> to the other to check if that still works temporarily?

any help would be great thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no wifi, Io0r error
threads.message:
IO0R error is probably bad traces from <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> to <CHIP>U5410</CHIP>.

Why are you changing parts? Did you even measure <SIGNAL>PM_WLAN_EN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no wifi, Io0r error
threads.message: i will check traces and report back. this is the first time I've had a board with no wifi and it not be the card/cable/connector issue, hence why i chose to start by replacing the card and cable. i will check for <SIGNAL>PM_WLAN_EN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>AP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>. also.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no wifi, Io0r error
threads.message: i do have 3.3v on <SIGNAL>PM_WLAN_EN_L</SIGNAL>, Ive got 0.135v on <SIGNAL>AP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>. i checked and no short to ground on this line. it looks like <SIGNAL>PW_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>XDP_DB2_PCH_GPIO10_AP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> which is the same 0.135v. would this be an issue with the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no wifi, Io0r error
threads.message: <CHIP>U5410</CHIP> pin5 is 2.4kohm pin4 0.0kohm also.would seem pin5 has a bad trace?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no wifi, Io0r error
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5410</CHIP> pin5 is 2.4kohm pin4 0.0kohm also.would seem pin5 has a bad trace?
No idea what you are doing here. Is it that difficult to measure 2 traces between <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR>/<CHIP>U5410</CHIP>?

Is <RESISTOR>R2067</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R2596</RESISTOR> good? Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>AP_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no wifi, Io0r error
threads.message: Not sure what im doing here either. have fun being a dick to everyone else.
